editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

sp.speaker: Lodovico.
sp.l: The truth is Piso, so she be a woman
And rich and wholesome, let her be of what
Condition and complexion it please,
She shall please me I am sure; those men are fools
That make their eyes their choosers, not their needs.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Methinks I would have her honest too, and handsome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes if I could have both, but since they are
Wishes so near impossibilities,
Let me have that that may be.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: If it were so,
I hope your conscience would not be so nice
To start at such a blessing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No believe me,
I do not think I should.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: But thou wouldst be
I do not doubt upon the least suspicion
Unmercifully jealous

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No I should not,
For I believe those mad that seek vexations,
A wife, though she be honest, is a trouble,
Had I a wife as fair as Helen was
That drew so many cuckolds to her cause,
These eyes should see another in my saddle
Ere I believe my beast would carry double.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: So should not I by'r lady, and I think
My patience (By your leave) as good as yours,
Report would stir me mainly, I am sure on't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Report? you are unwise; report is nothing;
For if there were a truth in what men talk,
I mean of this kind, this part of the world
I am sure would be no more called Christendom.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why cuckoldom, for we should lose
Our old faiths clean, and hold their new opinions:
If talk could make me sweat, before I would marry,
I'd tie a surer knot, and hang myself;
I tell thee there was never woman yet,
Nor never hope there shall be, though a saint,
But she has been a subject to men's tongues,
And in the worse sense: and that desperate husband,
That dares give up his peace, and follow humours
(Which he shall find too busy, if he seek 'em)
Beside the forcing of himself an ass
He dies in chains, eating himself with anger.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Having these antidotes against opinion
I would marry any one; an arrant whore.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thou dost not feel the nature of this physic
Which I prescribe not to beget diseases,
But where they are, to stop them.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: I conceive ye.
What thinkest thou? thy way of the widow Lelia?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faith thou hast found out one I must confess
Would stagger my best patience: from that woman
As I would bless myself from plagues and surfeits
From men a war at sea, from storms, and quicksands,
From hearing treason and concealing it,
From daring of a madman, or a drunkard,
From heresy, ill wine, and stumbling post-horse ;
So would I pray each morning, and each night
(And if I said each hour, I should not lie)
To be delivered of all these in one,
The woman thou hast named.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Thou hast set her in a pretty litany.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray take my council.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: When I am myself
I'll hear you any way; love me though thus
As thou art honest, which I dare not be
Lest I despise myself. Farewell. Exit. Julio.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Do you hear my friend: sir are you not a setter,
For the fair widow here of famous memory?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ha? am I taken for a bawd? o God
To mine own child too? misery, I thank thee
That keeps me from their knowledge: sir believe me
I understand ye not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You love plain dealing.
Are you not parcel bawd? confess your function,
It may be we would use it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Were she worse,
As I fear strangely she is ill enough,
I would not hear this tamely.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Here's a shilling
To strike good luck withal.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Here's a sword sir
To strike a knave withal, thou liest, and basely,
Be what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why how now gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You are many: I shall meet you, sir, again,
And make you understand, you've wronged a woman
Compared with whom thy mother was a sinner. Farewell. Exit Fa.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: He has amazed me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: With a blow?
By'r lady 'twas a sound on; are ye good
At taking knocks? I shall know you hereafter:
You wear too blame to tempt a man so far
Before you knew him certain: has not hurt ye?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: No I think.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: We were too blame indeed to go so far,
For men may be mistaken: if he had swinged us
He'd served us right: beshrew my heart I think,
We have done the gentlewoman as much wrong too,
For hang me, if I know her
In my particular.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Nor I; this 'tis to credit
Men's idle tongues; I warrant they have said
As much by our two mothers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Like enough.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I see a beating now and then does more
Move and stir up a man's contrition
Then a sharp sermon, here probatum est.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What shall I tell your sister?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Tell her this,
Till she be better conversationed
And leave her walking by herself, and whining
To her old melancholy lute, I'll keep
As far from her as the gallows. Exit servant.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Who's that Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes marry is't. O Angelo how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Save you sir, how does my mistress?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She is in love I think, but not with you.
I can assure you, saw ye Fabritio?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Is he come over?

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: Yes a week ago: shall we dine?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cannot:

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prithee do.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Believe me I have business.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Have you too, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why then let's dine together:

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Go then: farewell good Angelo,
Commend me to your friend.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Do not dissemble Franc, mine eyes are quicker
Than such observers, that do ground their faith
Upon one smile or tear; you're much altered,
And are as empty of those excellencies
That were companions to you; I mean mirth
And free disposure of your blood and spirit,
As you were born a mourner.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How I prithee?
For I perceive no such change in myself.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.l: Come, come, this is not wise, nor provident
To halt before a cripple: if you love
Be liberal to your friend, and let her know it,
I see the way you run, and know how tedious
'Twill prove without a true companion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sure thou wouldst have me love.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Yes marry would I
I should not please ye else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And who for god's sake?
For I assure myself, I know not yet:
And prithee Clora, since thou'lt have it so
That I must love, and do I know not what:
Let him behold a pretty handsome fellow,
And young, and if he be a little valiant
'Twill be the better; and a little wise
And faith a little honest.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Well I will sound ye yet for all your craft.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Heigh ho! I'll love no more.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Then one; and him
You shall love frank.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Which him? thou art so wise
People will take thee shortly for a witch:
But prithee tell me Clora, if I were
So mad as thou wouldst make me, what kind of man
Wouldst thou imagine him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Faith some pretty fellow?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: With a clean strength, that cracks a cudgel well
And dances at a wake, and plays at nine holes.
O God what pretty commendations thou hast given him '
Faith if were in love, as I thank God
I do not think I am; this short epistle
Before my love would make me burn the legend.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: You are too wild, I mean some gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: So do not I, till I can know 'em wiser:
Some gentleman, no Clora, till some gentleman
Keep some land, and fewer whores believe me
I'll keep no love for him, I do not long
To go a foot yet, and solicit causes.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: What think you then of an adventurer?
I mean some wealthy merchant.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Let him venture
In some decayed crare of his own: he shall not
Rig me out, that's the short on't; out upon't:
What young thing of my years would endure
To have her husband in another country
Within a month after she is married
Chopping for rotten raisins, and lie pining
At home under the mercy of his foreman? no,
Though they be wealthy, and indifferent wise
I do not see that I am bound to love 'em.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: I see you're hard to please; yet I will please ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Faith not so hard neither, if considered;
What woman may deserve as? she is worthy:
But why do we bestow our time so idly?
Prithee let us entertain some other talk,
This is as sickly to me as faint weather.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Now I believe I shall content you Frank,
What think you of a courtier?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Faith so ill,
That if I should be full, and speak but truth,
'Twould show as if I wanted charity,
Prithee good wench let me not rail upon 'em,
Yet I have an excellent stomach, and must do it;
I have no mercy of these infidels;
Since I am put in mind on't, good bear with me,
Can no man fit you? I will find him out.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This summer fruit, that you call courtier,
While you continue cold and frosty to him
Hangs fast, and may be found: but when you fling
Too full a heat of your affections —
Upon his root and make him ripe too soon,
You'llfind him rotten ith' the handling;
His oaths and affections are all one
With his apparel, things to set him off,
He has as many mistresses, as faithes,
And all apocryphas; his true belief
Is only in a private surgeon,
And for my single self, I'd sooner venture —
A new conversion of the Jndies,
Then to make courtiers, able men or honest.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I do believe you love no courtier,
And by my troth to guess you into love
With any I can think of; is beyond
Either your will, or my imagination.
And yet I am sure you're caught: and I will know him,
There's none left now worthy the thinking of;
Unless it be a soldier, and I am sure,
I would ever bless myself from such a fellow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why prithee?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Out upon 'em firelocks,
They are nothing ith' world, but buff and scarlet,
Tough unhewn pieces, to hack swords upon;
I had as lief be courted by a cannon,
As one of those.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thou art too malicious,
Upon my faith methinks they're worthy men.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Say ye so? I'll pull ye on a little further.
What worth can be in those men, whose profession
Is nothing ith' world but drink and damn me,
Out of whose violence they are possessed
With legions of unwholesome whores and quarrels;
I am of that opinion, and will die in't,
There is no understanding, nor can be
In a soused soldier.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now 'tis ignorance
I easily perceive that thus provokes thee,
And not the love of truth; I'll lay my life
If God had made thee man, thou hadst been a coward.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: If to be valiant, be to be a soldier; I'll tell ye true,
I had rather be a coward, I am sure with less sin.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This heresy must be looked too in time: for if it spread
'Twill grow too pestilent; were I a scholar
I would so hamper thee for thy opinion,
That ere I left, I would write thee out of credit
With all the world, and make thee not believed
Even in indifferent things; that I would leave thee
A reprobate out of the state of honour.
By all good things, thou hast flung aspersions
So like a fool (For I am angry with thee)
Upon a sort of men; (That let me tell thee
Thy mother's mother would have been a saint
Had she conceived a soldier) they are people
(I may commend 'em, while I speak but truth)
Of all the old world, only left to keep
Man as he was, valiant and virtuous:
They are the model of those men, whose honours
We heave our hands at when we hear recited.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: They are, and I have all I sought for, 'tis a soldier
You love, hide it no longer; you have betrayed yourself;
Come, I have found your way of commendations,
And what I said, was but to pull it from ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Twas pretty, are you grown so cunning, Clora?
I grant I love a soldier; but what soldier
Will be a new task to ye? But all this
I do imagine was but laid to draw me
Out of my melancholy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I will have the man
Ere I forsake ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I must to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: May not I go along?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, but good wench
Move me no more with these fond questions,
They work like rhubarb with me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Well, I will not. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Laelia and her waiting woman.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: How now? who was that you stayed to speak withal.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: The old man forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: What old man?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: The poor old man that uses to come hither he that you call father.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Have you dispatched him?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: No; he would fain speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Wilt thou never learn more manners, than to draw in such
Needy rascals to disquiet me? go, answer him I will
Not be at leisure.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: He will needs speak with you; and good old man he weeps so,
That by my troth I have not the heart to deny him, pray let you are not in love
Him speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Lord how tender stomached you are grown of late?
With him, are ye; if ye be, strike up the match; you shall have
Three, l. and a pair of blankets; will ye go answer him?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Pray let him speak with you, he will not away else.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Well, let him in then if there be no remedy; I thank God I am
Able to abuse him, i shall ne'er come clear else of him.
Now sir what is your business? pray be short; for I have other
Matters of more moment to call me from ye.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: If you but look upon me like a daughter
And keep that love about ye that makes good
A father's hope, you'll quickly find my business,
And what I would say to you, and before
I ask, will be a giver: say that sleep,
I mean that love, or be but numbed within ye,
The nature of my want is such a searcher,
And of so mighty power, that where he finds
This dead forgetfulness, it works so strongly,
That if the least heat of a child's affection
Remain unperished, like another nature,
It makes all new again; pray do not scorn me,
Nor seem to make yourself a greater business
Than my relieving.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: If you were not old
I should laugh at ye; what a vengeance ails ye
To be so childish to imagine me
A founder of old fellows? make him drink wench,
And if there be any cold meat in the buttery,
Give him some broken bread and that, and rid him.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Is this a child's love? or a recompense
Fit for a father's care? O Lelia,
Had I been thus unkind, thou hadst not been;
Or like me miserable: but 'tis impossible
Nature should die so utterly within thee,
And lose her promises; thou art one of those
She set her stamp more excellently on,
Then common people, as foretelling thee
A general example of her goodness;
Or say she could lie, yet religion
(For love to parents is religious)
Would lead thee right again: look well upon me
I am the root that gave thee nourishment,
And made thee spring fair, do not let me perish
Now I am old and sapless.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: As I live
I like ye far worse now ye grow thus holy,
I grant you are my father; am I therefore
Bound to consume myself and be a beggar
Still in relieving you? I do not feel
Any such mad compassion yet within me.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I gave up all my state to make yours thus.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: 'Twas as ye ought to do, and now ye cry for't
As children do for babies back again.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: How wouldst thou have me live?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I would not have ye,
Nor know no reason fathers should desire
To live, and be a trouble, when children
Are able to inherit, let them die,
'Tis fit, and looked for, that they should do so.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Is this your comfort?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: All that I feel yet.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I will not curse thee.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: If you do I care not.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Pray you give me leave to weep

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Why pray take leave,
If it be for your ease.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Thy mother died,
Sweet peace be with her, in a happy time.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: She did sir, as she ought to do, would you
Would take the pains to follow; what should you
Or any old man do wearing away
In this world with diseases, and desire
Only to live to make their children scourge-sticks,
And hoard up mill-money? methinks a marble
Lies quieter upon an old man's head
Then a cold fit a'th palsy.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O good God!
To what an impudence thou wretched woman,
Hast thou begotten thyself again! well, justice
Will punish disobedience.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You mistake sir;
'Twill punish beggars, fie for shame go work
Or serve, you are grave enough to be a porter
In some good man of worship's house, and give
Sententious answers to the comers in,
A pretty place; or be of some good consort,
You had a pleasant touch a'th' cithron once,
If idleness have not bereft you of it:
Be any thing but old, and beggarly,
Two sins that ever do out grow compassion;
If I might see you offer at a course
That were a likely one, and showed some profit,
I would not stick for ten groats, or a noble.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Did I beget this woman?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Nay, I know not:
And till I know, I will not thank you for't;
However , he that got me had the pleasure,
And that methinks , is a reward sufficient.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I am so strangely strooken with amazement,
I know not where I am, nor what I am.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You had best take fresh air somewhere else, 'twill bring ye
Out of your trance the sooner.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Is all this
As you mean Lelia?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Yes believe me is it,
For yet I cannot think you are so foolish,
As to imagine you are young enough
To be my heir, or I so old to make
A nurse at these years for you, and attend
While you sup up my state in penny pots
Of malmsey: when I am excellent at caudles,
And cullises. and have enough spare gold
To boil away, you shall be welcome to me;
Till when I'd have you be as merry sir
As you can make yourself with that you have,
And leave to trouble me with these relations;
Of what you have been to me, or you are,
For as I hear them, so I lose them; this
For ought I know yet, is me resolution.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Well God be with thee, for I fear thy end
Will be a strange example. Exit father.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Fare ye well sir;
Now would some poor tender hearted fool have wept,
Relented, and have been undone: such children
I thank my understanding I hate truly,
For by my troth I had rather see their tears;
Then feel their pities: my desires and ends
Are all the kindred that I have, and friends. Enter woman.
Is he departed?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Yes, but here's another.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Not of his tribe I hope; bring me no more
I would wish you such as he is, if thou seest
They look like men of worth, and state, and carry
Ballast of both sides like tall gentlemen
Admit 'em, but no snakes to poison us
With poverty; wench you must learn a wise rule,
Look not upon the youths of men, and making,
How they descend in blood, nor let their tongues
Though they strike suddenly, and sweet as music
Corrupt thy fancy: see, and say them fair too,
But ever keep thyself without their distance:
Unless the love thou swallows be a pill,
Gilded to hide the bitterness it brings,
Then fall on without fear wench, yet so wisely
That one encounter cloy him not; nor promise
His love hath made thee more his, than his moneys;
Learn this and thrive,
Then let thine honour ever,
(For that's the last rule) be so stood upon,
That men may fairly see
'Tis want of means, not virtue makes thee fall;
And if you weep 'twill be a great deal better,
And draw on more compassion, which includes
A greater tenderness of love and bounty;
This is enough at once, digest it well:
Go let him in wench, if he promise profit,
Not else.
O you are welcome my fair servant,
Upon my troth I have been longing for ye.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: This, by her rule should be a liberal man,
I see the best on's may learn every day.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: There's none come with you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You do the wiser,
For some that have been here (I name no man)
Out of their malice, more than truth, have done me
Some few ill offices.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How, sweet?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Nay nothing,
Only have talked a little wildly of me;
As their unruly youth directed 'em:
Which though they bite me not, I would have wished
Had light upon some other that deserved 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Though she deserve this of the loosest tongue,
(Which makes my sin the more) I must not see it;
Such is my misery: I would I knew him.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: No, no, let him go,
He is not worth your anger: I must chide you
For being such a stranger to your mistress,
Why would you be so, servant?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I should chide,
If chiding would work any thing upon you:
For being such a stranger to your servant,
I mean to his desires: when my dear mistress,
Shall I be made a happy man?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Fie servant
What do you mean, unhand me, or by heaven,
I shall be very angry, this is rudeness.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Twas but a kiss or two, that thus offends you

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: 'Twas more I think then you have warrant for.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am sorry I deserved no more.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You may,
But not this rough way servant: we are tender,
And ought in all to be respected so;
If I had been your horse, or whore, you might
Back me with this intemperance; I thought
You had loved as worthy men, whose fair affections
Seek pleasures warranted, not pulled by violence,
Do so no more.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I hope you are not angry?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I should be with another man, I am sure,
That durst appear but half thus violent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I did not mean to ravish ye

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You couldn't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You are so willing —

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Methinks this shadow,
If you had so much shame as fits a woman:
At least of your way, mistress, long ere this
Had been laid of to me that understand ye.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: That understand me? Sir ye understand,
Nor shall no more of me then modesty,
Will without fear deliver to a stranger;
You understand I am honest; else I tell ye
(Though you were better far than Julio)
You, and your understanding are two fools,
But were we saints, thus we are still rewarded.
I see that woman had a pretty catch on't,
That had made you the master of a kindnesses,
She durst not answer openly; oh me!
How easily we women may be cozened?
I took this Julio as I have a faith,
(This young dissembler with the sober vizard)
For the most modest tempered gentleman,
The coolest, quietest, and best companion;
For such an one I could have wished a woman.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have wished me ill enough a conscience,
Make me no worse for shame: I see the more
I work by way of service to obtain ye
You work the more upon me. Tell me truly
(While I am able to believe a woman,
For if you use me thus, that faith will perish)
What is your end, and whether will you pull me?
Tell me, but tell me that I may not start at,
And have a cause to curse ye.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Bless me goodness!
To curse me did you say sir? let it be
For too much loving you then, such a curse
Kill me withal and I shall be a martyr;
You have found a new way to reward my doting,
And I confess a fit one for my folly,
For you yourself if you have good within ye,
And dare be master of it, know how deadly
This heart has held you ever; o good God!
That I had never seen that false man's eyes,
That dare reward me thus with fears and curses,
Nor never heard the sweetness of that tongue,
That will when this is known, yet cozen women:
Curse me good Julio, curse me bitterly,
I do deserve it for my confidence,
And I beseech thee, if thou hast a goodness
Of power yet in thee to confirm thy wishes,
Curse me to earth; for what should I do here
Like a decaying flower, still withering
Under his bitter words, whose kindly heat
Should give my poor heart life? No, curse me Julio,
Thou canst not do me such a benefit
As that, and well done, that the heavens may hear it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O fair tears were you but as chaste, as subtle,
Like bones of saints, ye would work miracles;
What were these women to a man that knew not
The thousand, thousand ways of their deceiving?
What riches had he found? O he would think
Himself still dreaming of a blessedness,
That like continual spring should flourish ever.
For if she were as good as she is seeming,
Or like an eagle could renew her virtues,
Nature had made another world of sweetness;
Be not so grieved sweet mistress, what I said
You do, or should know, was but passion;
Pray wipe your eyes and kiss me; take these trifles,
And wear them for me, which are only rich
When you will put them on; indeed I love ye,
Beshrew my sick heart, if I grieve not for ye.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Will you dissemble still? I am a fool,
And you may easily rule me, if you flatter,
The sin will be your own.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You know I do not.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: And shall I be so childish once again,
After my late experience of your spite
To credit you? you do not know how deep
(Or if you did, you would be kinder to me,)
This bitterness of yours have struck my heart.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I pray no more.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Thus you would do I warrant,
If I were married to you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Married to me?
Is that your end?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Yes, is not that the best end,
And as all hold, the noblest way of love?
Why do you look so strange sir? do not you
Desire it should be so?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Answer me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Farewell. Exit Julio.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Ay, are you there? are all these tears lost then?
Am I so overtaken by a fool
In my best days and tricks? my wise fellow
I'll make you smart for't as I am a woman,
And if thou beest not timber, yet I'll warm thee:
And is he gone?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: He's not so lightly struck
To be recovered with a base repentance,
I should be sorry then: fortune I prithee
Give me this man but once more in my arms,
And if I lose him, women have no charms. Exeunt omnes

sp.speaker: Jaco.
sp.l: Seigneur, what think you of this sound of wars?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: As only of a sound; they that intend
To do are like deep waters that run quietly
Leaving no face of what they were behind 'em,
This rumour is too common and too loud
To carry truth.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Shall we never live to see
Men look like men again,
Upon a march?
This cold dull rusty peace makes us appear
Like empty pictures, only the faint shadows
Of what we should be:
Would to God my mother
Had given but half her will to my begetting
And made me woman, to sit still and sing,
Or be sick when I list, or any thing
That is too idle for a man to think of:
Would I had been a whore 'thad been a course
Certain, and of my conscience of more gain
Than two commands, as I would handle it:
Faith I could wish I had been any thing
Rather than what I am, a soldier
A career, or a cobbler, when I knew
What 'twas to wear a sword first; for their trades
Are and shall be a constant way of life,
While men send cheeses up, or wear out buskins.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou art a little too impatient,
And mak'st thy anger a far more vexation
Than the not having wars: I am a soldier
Which is my whole inheritance, yet I
Though I could wish a breach with all the world
If not dishonourable, I am not so malicious,
To curse the fair peace of my mother country;
But thou wantest money; and the first supply
Will bury these thoughts in thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Pox a peace.
It fills the kingdom full of holidays,
And only feeds the wants of whores and pipers;
And make the idle drunken rogues, get spinsters.
'Tis true I may want money, and no little,
And almost clothes too: of which if I had both
In full abundance: yet against all peace,
That brings up mischief thicker than a shower,
I would speak louder than a lawyer;
By heaven it is the surfeit of all youth,
That makes the toughness, and the strength of nations
Melt into women. 'tis an ease that brood's
Thieves, and bastards only.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: This is more,
(Though it be true) then we ought to lay open,
And seasons only of an indiscretion,
Believe me captain such distempered spirits
Once out of motion, though they be proof valiant,
If they appear thus violent and fiery,
Breed but their own disgraces; and are nearer
Doubt, and suspect in princes, than rewards.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis well they can be near 'em any way,
But call you those true spirits, ill affected
That whilst the wars were, served like walls and ribs,
To girdle in the kingdom?
And now fallen
Through a faint peace into affliction,
Speak but their miseries? come, come, Fabritio
You may pretend what patience ye please,
And seem to yoke your wants like passions;
But while I know thou art a soldier,
And a deserver, and no other harvest
But what thy sword reaps for thee to come in,
You shall be pleased to give me leave to tell ye,
You wish a devil of this musty peace:
To which prayer,
As one that's bound in conscience, and all
That love our trade, I cry, amen.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Prithee no more, we shall live well enough,
There's ways enough besides the wars to men
That are not logs, and lie still for the hands
Of others to remove 'em.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You may thrive sir,
Thou art young and handsome yet, and well enough
To please a widow: thou canst sing, and tell
These foolish love-tales; and indite a little,
And if need be, compile, a pretty matter
And dedicate it to the honourable,
Which may awaken his compassion,
To make ye clerk a'th kitchen, and at length
Come to be married to my lady's woman,
After she's cracked ith' ring.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis very well sir.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: But what dost thou think shall become of me,
With all my imperfections? let me die
If I think I shall ever reach above
A forlorn tapster, or some frothy fellow,
That stinks of stale beer.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Captain Jacamo,
Why should you think so hardly of your virtues?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What virtues? by this light I have no virtue,
But down right buffeting: what can my face
That is no better than a ragged map now
Of where I have marched and travelled profit me?
Unless it be for ladies to abuse, and say
'Twas spoiled for want of a Bongrace when I was young,
And now 'twill make a true prognostication
Of what man must be? Tell me of a fellow
That can mend noses, and complain,
So tall a soldier should want teeth to his stomach?
And how it was great pity, that it was,
That he that made my body, was so busied
He could not stay to make my legs too? but was driven
To clap a pair of catskins to my knees, for which
I am indebted to two schoolboys? this
Must follow necessary.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: There's no such matter.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Then for my morals, and those hidden pieces,
That art bestows upon me, they are such
That when they come to light: I am sure will shame me.
For I can neither write, nor read, nor speak
That any man shall hope to profit by me,
And for my languages, they are so many
That put them altogether, they will scarce
Serve to beg single beer in: the plain truth is,
I love a soldier, and can lead him on,
And if he fight well I dare make him drunk:
This is my virtue, and if this will do
I'll scramble yet amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis your way
To be thus pleasant still, but fear not man
For though the wars fail, we shall screw ourselves
Into some course of life yet.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Good Fabritio,
Have a quick eye upon me, for I fear
This peace will make me something that I love not;
For by my troth though I am plain and dudgeon,
I would not be an ass: and to sell parcels,
I can as soon be hanged; prithee bestow me
And speak some little good, though I deserve not.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come we'll consider more: stay, this
Should be another windfall of the wars.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He looks indeed like an old tattered colours,
That every wind would borrow from the staff;
These are the hopes we have for all our hurts:
They have not cast his tongue too.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: They that say
Hope never leaves a wretched man that seeks her,
I think are either patient fools, or liars,
I am sure I find it so, for I am mastered,
With such a misery and grief together
That that staid anchor men lay hold upon
In all their needs, is to me lead that bows,
Or breaks, with every strong sea of my sorrows.
I could now question heaven, (Were it well
To look into their justice) why those faults,
Those heavy sins, other provoke 'em with
Should be rewarded on the heads of us,
That hold the least alliance to their vices?
But this would be too curious; for I see
Our suffering, not disputing, is the end,
Revealed to us of all these miseries.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Twenty such holy hermits in a camp,
Would make 'em all Carthusians, I'll be hanged
If he know what a whore is: or a health,
Or have a nature liable to learn,
Or so much honest nurture to be drunk.
I do not think he has the spleen to swear
A greater oath than sempsters utter socks with,
S'pur him a question.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: They are strangers both
To me, as I to them I hope: I would not have
Me and my shame together known by any,
I'll rather lie myself unto another.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I need not ask you sir your country,
I hear you speak this tongue: pray what more are ye?
Or have you been? if it be not offensive
To urge ye so far, misery in your years,
Gives every thing a tongue to question it.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Sir, though I could be pleased to make my ills
Only mine own, for grieving other men,
Yet to so fair and courteous a demander
That promises compassion, at worst, pity,
I will relate a little of my story.
I am a gentleman, however thus
Poor and unhappy; which believe me sir
Was not born with me: for I well have tried
Both the extremes of fortune; and have found
Both dangerous: my younger years provoked me,
Feeling in what an case I slept at home,
Which to all stirring spirits is a sickness,
To see far countries, and observe their customs.
I did so; and I travelled till that course
Stored me with language, and some few slight manners,
Scarce worth my money; when an ich possessed me
Of making arms my active end of travel.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: But did you so?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I did; and twenty winters
I wore the Christian cause upon my sword
Against his enemies, at Buda siege
Full many a cold night have I lodged in armour
When all was frozen in me but mine honour:
And many a day, when both the sun and cannon
Strove, who should most destroy us: have I stood
Malled up in steel, when my rough sinews shrunk,
And this parched body ready to consume
As soon to ashes, as the pike I bore:
Want has been to me as another nature,
Which makes me with this patience still profess it;
And if a soldier may without vainglory
Tell what has done, believe me gentlemen
I could turn over annals of my dangers:
With this poor weakness have I manned a breach,
And made it firm with so much blood, that all
I had to bring me off alive was anger.
Thrice was I made a slave, and thrice redeemed
At price of all I had; the miseries
Of which times, if I had a heart to tell,
Would make ye weep like children; but I'll spare ye

sp.speaker: Ja
sp.l: Fabricio, we two have been soldiers
Above these fourteen years, yet a my conscience
All we have seen, compared to his experience
Has been but cudgel-play, or cockfighting.
By all the faith I have in arms, I reverence
The very poverty of this brave fellow:
Which were enough itself, and his to strengthen
The weakest town against half Christendom.
I was never so ashamed of service
In all my life before, now I consider
What I have done; and yet the rogues would swear
I was a valiant fellow; I do find
The greatest danger I have brought my life through,
Now I have heard this worthy, was no more
Than stealing of a maypole, or at worst,
Fighting at single billet with a bargeman.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I do believe him Jacamo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Believe him?
I have no faith within me, if I do not.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I see they are soldiers?
And if we may judge by affections
Brave and deserving men: how they are stirred
But with a mere relation of what may be?
Since I have won belief, and am not known,
Forgive me honour, I'll make use of thee.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Sir would I were a man, or great, or able
To look with liberal eyes upon your virtue.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Let's give him all we have, and leave off prating:
Here soldier, there's even five months pay: be merry,
And get thee handsome clothes.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What mean you Jacamo?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ye are a fool.
The very story's worth a hundred pound.
Give him more money.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Gentlemen, I know not
How I am able to deserve this blessing.
But if I live to see fair days again,
Something I'll do in honour of your goodness,
That shall show thankfulness, if not desert.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: If you please sir, till we procure ye place,
To eat with us, or wear such honest garments
As our poor means can reach to, you shall be
A welcome man; to say more, were to feed ye
Only with words; we honour what you've been,
For we are soldiers, though not near the worth
You spoke of lately.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I do guess ye so,
And knew, unless he were a soldier,
He could not find the way to know my wants.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But methinks all this while you're too temperate;
Do you not tell men sometimes of their dulness
When you are gripped, as now you are with need?
I do, and let them know those silks they wear
The war weaves for 'em: and the bread they eat
We sow, and reap again to feed their hunger:
I tell them boldly, they are masters of
Nothing but what we fight for: their fair women
Lie playing in their arms, whilst we like lares
Defend their pleasures: I am angry too,
And often rail at these forgetful great men
That suffer us to sue for what we ought
To have flung on us, ere we ask.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I have
Too often told my griefs that way, when all
I reaped, was rudeness of behaviour;
In their opinions men of war that thrive,
Must thank 'em when they rail: and wait to live.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come sir, I see your wants need more relieving,
Then looking what they are: pray go with us.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I thank you gentlemen: since you are pleased
To do a benefit, I dare not cross it,
And what my service or endeavours may
Stand you in need, you shall command, not pray.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: So you shall us; I'll to the tailors with you bodilyExeunt

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, if this be true; I'll believe a woman
When I have nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: 'Tis certain; if there be a way of truth,
In blushes, smiles, and commendations;
For by this light, have heard her praise you fellow
In such a pitch, as if she'd studied
To crowd the worths of all men into him,
And I imagine these are seldom used
Without their special ends, and by a maid
Of her desires and youth.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It may be so.
She's free as you or I am, and may have
By that prerogative, a liberal choice
In the bestowing of her love.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.l: Bestowing?
If it be so, she has bestowed herself
Upon a trim youth: Piso, what do you call him?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Why, captain Jacamo.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O captain jack-boy,
That is the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I think he be
A gentleman at worst.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: So think I too,
Would he would mend sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And a tall one too.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes of his teeth; for of my faith I think
They are sharper than his sword, and dare do more
If the beuffe meet him fairly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Now do I wonder what she means to do
When she has married him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why well enough,
Trail his pike under him, and be a gentlewoman
Of the brave captain's company.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do you hear me?
This woman is my sister, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am glad she is none of mine: but Frederick,
Thou art not such a fool sure to be angry
Unless it be with her; we are thy friends man.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I think ye are.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes faith, and do but tell thee
How she will utterly o'erthrow her credit,
If she continue gracing of this potgun.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: I think she was bewitched, or mad, or blind,
She would never have taken such a scarecrow else
Into protection: of my life he looks
Of a more rusty swarth complexion
Then an old arming doublet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I would send
His face to the cutlers then, and have it sanguined,
'Twill look a great deal sweeter; then his nose
I would have shorter, and my reason is,
His face will be ill mounted else.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: For his body,
I will not be my own judge, lest I seem
A railer, but let others look upon't,
And if they find it any other thing
Than a trunk-seller, to send wines down in,
Or a long walking-bottle, I'll be hanged for't:
His hide, (For sure he is a beast) is ranker
Than the Muscovy leather: and grained like it.
And by all likelihoods he was begotten
Between a stubborn pair of winter boots.
His body goes with straps, he is so churlish.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He's poor and beggarly besides all this:
And of a nature far uncapable
Of any benefit: for his manners cannot
Show him a way to thank a man that does one,
He's so uncivil: you may do a part
Worthy a brother, to persuade your sister
From her undoing: if she prove so foolish
To marry this cast captain, look to find her
Within a month, where you, or any good man
Would blush to know her: selling cheese and prunes,
And retailed bottle ale: I grieve to think
Because I loved her, what a march this captain
Will set her into.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You are both, believe me,
Two arrant knaves; and were it not for taking
So just an execution from his hands
You have belied thus, I would swaddle ye,
Till I could draw off both your skins like scabbards.
That man that you wronged thus, though to me
He be a stranger, yet I know, so worthy,
However low in fortune, that his worst parts,
The very wearing of his clothes, would make
Two better gentlemen than you dare be,
For there is virtue in his outward things.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Belike you love him then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes marry do I.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And will be angry for him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If you talk
Or pull your face into a stitch again,
As I love truth I shall be very angry.
Do not I know thee, though thou hast some land
To set thee out thus among gentlemen,
To be a prating and vainglorious ass?
I do not wrong thee now, for I speak truth.
Do not I know thou hast been a cudgeled coward,
That has no cure for shame but cloth of silver?
And thinkst the wearing of a gawdy suit
Hides all disgraces?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I understand you not, you hurt not me
Your anger flies so wide.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Signior Frederick,
You much mistake this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: If you would please to be less angry,
I would tell you how.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You had better study sir
How to excuse yourself if ye be able,
Or I shall tell you once again.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Not me sir;
For I protest what I have said, was only
To make you understand your sister's danger.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He might if it pleased him conceive it so.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I might if it pleased me stand still and hear
My sister made a may-game, might I not?
And give allowance to your liberal jests
Upon his person, whose least anger would
Consume a legion of such wretched people,
That have no more to justify their actions
But their tongues ends? that dare lie every way
As a mill grinds? From this hour I renounce
All part of fellowship that may hereafter
Make me take knowledge of ye, but for knaves;
And take heed, as ye love whole skins, and coxcombs,
How, and to whom ye prate thus; for this time
I care not if I spare ye: do not shake,
I will not beat ye, though ye do deserve it
Richly.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This is a strange course Frederick;
But sure you do not, or you would not know us,
Beat us?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: 'Tis somewhat low sir, to a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I'll speak but few words, but I'll make 'em truths;
Get you gone both, and quickly, without murmuring,
Or looking big: and yet before you go
I will have this confessed, and seriously,
That you two are two rascals.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Two rascals.
Come speak it from your hearts, or by this light
My sword shall fly among ye; answer me,
And to the point directly.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: You shall have
Your will for this time: since we see you're grown
So far untemperate; let it be so sir
In your opinion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do not mince the matter,
But speak the words plain; and you Lodovick
That stand so tally on your reputation,
You shall be he shall speak it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This is pretty,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let me not stay upon't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well we are rascals,
Yes Piso, we are rascals. Exit Lod. and Piso.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Get ye gone now, not a word more, you're rascals.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: That should be Frederick.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis he: Frederick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: A friend sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is so, by the voice
I have sought you gentlemen, and since I have found you,
So near our house, I'll force ye stay a while,
I pray let it be so.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: It is too late,
We'll come and dine tomorrow with your sister,
And do our services.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Who were those with you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We met two came from hence:
Two idle fellows,
That you shall beat hereafter, and I'll tell ye
Some fitter time a cause sufficient for it.

sp.speaker: Fabr.
sp.l: But Frederick, tell me truly; do you think
She can affect my friend?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No certainer
Than when I speak of him, or any other,
She entertains it with as much desire
As others do their recreations.

sp.speaker: Fabr.
sp.l: Let not him have this light by any means;
He will but think he's mocked, and so grow angry,
Even to a quarrel: he's so much distrustful
Of all that take occasion to commend him —
Women especially: for which he shuns
All conversation with 'em, and believes
He can be but a mirth to all their sex.
Whence is this music?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: From my sister's chamber.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: The touch is excellent 'Let's be attentive.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Hark, are the weights abroad?

sp.speaker: Fabr.
sp.l: Be softer prithee,
'Tis private music.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What a din it makes?
I had rather hear a jews-trump than these lutes,
They cry like schoolboys.

sp.speaker: Fabr.
sp.l: Prithee Jacamo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well I hear, or sleep, I care not whether.

body.head: The song.
body.stage: Enter at the window Francke and Clora.

sp.l: Tell me dearest what is love?
'Tis a lightning from above,
'Tis an arrow, 'tis a fire,
'Tis a boy they call desire.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: 'Tis a grave,
Gapes to have
Those poor fools that long to prove.
Tell me more, are women true?
Yes, some are, and some as you.
Some are willing, some are strange,
Since you men first taught to change.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: And till troth
Be in both,
All shall love, to love anew.
Tell me more yet, can they grieve?
Yes, and sicken sore, but live:
And be wise, and delay,
When you men are as wise as they.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Then I see
Faith will be,
Never till they both believe.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Clora, come hither; who are these below there?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Ha? I should know their shapes
Though it be darkish; there are both our brothers,
What should they make thus late here?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What's the tother?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: What tother?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He that lies along there.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: O, I see him
As if he had a branch of some great pedigree
Grew out on's belly.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: That should be,
If I have any knowledge in proportion. —

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: They see us.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What a log
Is this, to sleep such music out?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No more let's hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: If I have any knowledge in proportion,
The captain Jacamo, those are his legs
Upon my conscience.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: By my faith, and neat ones.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: You mean the boots, I think they are neat by nature,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: As thou art knavish, would I saw his face!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: 'Twould scare you in the dark.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A worse than that
Has never scared you Clora to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.l: 'Tis true, for I never have seen a worse;
Nor while I say my prayers heartily,
I hope I shall not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well, I am no tell tale:
But is it not great pity, tell me Clora,
That such a brave deserving gentleman
As every one delivers this to be,
Should have no more respect, and worth flung on him
By able men? Were I one of these great ones,
Such virtues should not sleep thus.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.l: Were he greater
He would sleep more I think: I'll waken him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Away ye fool.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Is he not dead already, and they two taking order
About his blacks? methinks they are very busy,
A fine clean corse he is: I would have him buried
Even as he lies, cross legged, like one o'th templars
(If his West-phaly gammons will hold crossing)
And on his breast, a buckler with a pike in't,
In which I would have some, learned Cutler
Compile an epitaph, and at his feet
A musket, with this word upon a label
Which from the cock's mouth thus should be delivered,
I have discharged the office of a soldier.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Well, if thy father were a soldier
Thus thou wouldst use him.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.l: Such a soldier,
I would indeed.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: If he hear this, not all
The power of man could keep him from the windows
Till they were down and all the doors broke open:
For God's sake make her cooler: I dare not venture
To bring him else: I know he will go to buffets
Within five words with her, if she holds this spirit;
Let's waken him, and away, we shall hear worse else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well if I be not even with thee Clora
Let me be hanged for this: I know thou dost it
Only to anger me, and purge your wit
Which would break out else.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.l: I have found ye,
I'll be no more cross, bid 'em good night

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, no, they shall not know, we have seen 'em;
Shut the window. Exit Fran. and Clora.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Will you get up sir?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Have you paid the fiddlers?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: You are not left to do it: fie upon thee,
Hast thou forsworn manners?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes unless
They would let me eat my meat without long graces
Or drink without a preface to the pledger;
Oft will it please you, shall I be so bold sir
Let me remember your good bedfellow,
And lie and kiss my hand unto my mistress
As often as an ape does for an apple;
These are mere schisms in soldiers; where's my friend?
These are to us as bitter as purgations,
We love that general freedom we are bred to;
Hang these faint fooleries, they smell of peace,
Do they not friend?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Faith sir to me they are
As things indifferent, yet I use 'em not,
Or if I did, they would not prick my conscience.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come, shall we go? 'tis late.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes any whither,
But no more music, it has made me dull.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Faith any thing but drinking disturbs thee Jacomo
We'll even to bed.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou wilt dream of wenches.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I never think of any I thank God
But when I am drunk, and then 'tis but to cast
A cheap way how they may be all destroyed
Like vermin; let's away I am very sleepy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ay, thou art ever so, or angry, come. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I will but see her once more Angilo
That I may hate her more, and then I am
Myself again.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I would not have thee tempt lust,
'Tis away dangerous, and will deceive thee
Hadst thou the constancy of all men in thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Having her sins before me, I dare see her
Were she as catching as the plague, and deadly,
And tell her she is fouler than all those
And far more pestilent, if not repentant,
And like a strong man, chide her well, and leave her.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: 'Tis easily said, of what complexion is she?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Make but a curious frame unto thyself
As thou wouldst shape an angel in thy thought
Such as the poets, when their fancies sweat
Imagine Juno is, or fair eyed Pallas
And one more excellent, than all those figures
Shalt thou find her; she's brown, but of a sweetness,
(If such a poor word may express her beauty)
Believe me Angilo would do more mischief
With a forc't smile, than twenty thousand Cupids
With their love quivers, full of ladies' eyes,
And twice as many flames, could fling upon us.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Of what age is she?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As a rose at fairest,
Neither a bud, nor blown, but such a one,
Were there a Hercules to get again
With all his glory, or one more than he
The god would choose out amongst a race of women
To make a mother of; she is outwardly
All that bewitches sense; all that entices,
Nor is it in our virtue to uncharm it.
And when she speaks, o Angilo, than music
(Such as old Orpheus made, that gave a soul
To aged mountains, and made rugged beasts
Lay by their rages; and tall trees that knew
No sound but tempests, to bow down their branches
And hear, and wonder; and the sea, whose surges
Shook their white heads in heaven, to be as midnight
Still, and attentive; steals into our souls
So suddenly, and strangely, that we are
From that time no more ours but what she pleases.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why look, how far you have thrust yourself again
Into your old disease? are you that man
With such a resolution, that would venture
To take your leave of folly, and now melt
Even in repeating her?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I had forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: As you will still do.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, the strongest man
May have the grudging of an ague on him,
This is no more; let's go, I would fain be fit
To be thy friend again, for now I am no man's.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Go you, I dare not go, I tell you truly
Nor were it wise I should.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am well.
And if I can, will keep myself so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ha? thou mak'st me smile, though I have little cause,
To see how prettily thy fear becomes thee;
Art thou not strong enough to see a woman?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes, twenty thousand: but not such a one
As you have made her; I'll not lie for'th matter:
I know I am frail, and may be cozened too
By such a Siren.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Faith thou shalt go, Angilo

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Faith but I will not; no I know how far sir
I am able to hold out, and will not venture
Above my depth: I do not long to have
My sleep taken from me, and go pulingly
Like a poor wench had lost her market money;
And when I see good meat, sit still and sigh,
And call for small beer; and consume my wit
In making anagrams, and faithful poses;
I do not like that itch, I am sure I had rather
Have the main pox, and safer.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou shalt go,
I must needs have thee as a witness with me
Of my repentance; as thou lovest me go.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well I will go, since you will have it so,
But if I prove a fool too, look to have me
Curse you continually, and fearfully.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And if thou seest me fall again, good Angilo
Give me thy council quickly lest I perish.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray God I have enough to save myself,
For as I have a soul, I had rather venture
Upon a savage island, than this woman.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: From whom sir, comes this bounty? for I think
You are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: No sir, 'tis to you,
I am sure my mistress sent it.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Who's your mistress,
That I may give her thanks?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The virtuous widow,

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: The virtuous widow sir? I know none such:
Pray what's her name?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Laelia.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I knew you erred
'Tis not to me I warrant ye; there sir,
Carry it to those she feeds fat with such favours,
I am a stranger to her.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Good sir take it,
And if you will, I'll swear she sent it to you,
For I am sure mine eye never went off ye
Since you forsook the gentlemen you talked with
Just at her door.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Indeed I talked with two
Within this half hour in the street.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis you sir,
And none but you I am sent to: wiser men
Would have been thankful sooner, and received it,
'Tis not a fortune every man can brag of,
And from a woman of her excellence.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Well sir, I am catechized; what more belongs to't ?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: This only sir; she would entreat you come
This evening to her without fail.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You guess where.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Sir I have a tongue else. Exit Ser.
She is downright devil; or else my wants
And her disobedience have provoked her
To look into her foul self, and be sorry.
I wonder how she knew me? I had thought
I had been the same to all, I am to them
That changed me thus: God pardon me for lying,
For I have paid it home: many a good man
That had but found the profit of my way
Would forswear telling true again in haste.
Here are my praters; now if I did well
I should be labour 'em, but I have found
A way to quiet 'em, worth a thousand on't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If we could get a fellow that would do it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What villainy is now in hand?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: 'Twill be hard to be done in my opinion
Unless we light upon an Englishman
With sevenscore surfeits in him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Are the Englishmen such stubborn drinkers?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Not a leak at sea
Can suck more liquor; you shall have their children
Christened in mulled sack, and at five years old, able
To knock a Dane down: take an Englishman
And cry st. George, and give him but a rasher,
And you shall have him upon even terms
Defy a hogshead; such a one would do it
Home boy, and like a workman: at what weapon?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sherry sack: I would have him drink stark dead,
If it were possible: at worst past pottage.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: What is the end then?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Dost thou not perceive it?
If he be drunk dead, there's a fair end of him.
If not, this is my end, or by enticing,
Or by deceiving, to conduct him where
The fool is, that admires him; and if sober,
His nature be so rugged, what will't be
When he is hot with wine? come let's about it,
If this be done but handsomely, I'll pawn
My head she hath done with soldiers.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: This may do well.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Here's a new way to murder men alive,
I'll choke this train: God save ye gentlemen.
It is to you, stay: yes it is to you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's to me?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: You are fortunate,
I cannot stand to tell you more now, meet me
Here soon, and you'll be made a man. Exit father.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What vision's this?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, I'll meet it,
Think you o'th' other, and let me a while
Dream of this fellow.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: For the drunkard, Lodowick,
Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come, let's about it then.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, pray let me laugh extremely.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why? prithee why? hast thou such cause?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes faith, my brother will be here straightway, and —

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The other party: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What party?
Wench thou art not drunk.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No faith.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Faith thou hast been among the bottles Clora;

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Faith but I have not Frank: prithee be handsome,
The captain comes along too, wench.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O is that it?
That tickles ye.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes, and shall tickle you too,
You understand me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: By my troth thou art grown
A strange lewd wench: I must e'en leave thy company,
Thou wilt spoil me else.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nay, thou art spoiled to my hand;
Hadst thou been free, as a good wench ought to be,
When I went first a birding for thy love,
And roundly said, that is the man must do it,
I had done laughing many an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And what dost thou see in him, now thou knowest him,
To be thus laughed at?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Prithee be not angry
And I'll speak freely to thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do, I will not.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Then as I hope to have a handsome husband,
This fellow in mine eye, and Frank I am held
To have a shrewd guess at a pretty fellow,
Appears a strange thing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why how strange for god's sake?
He is a man, and one that may content
(For any thing I see) a right good woman:
And sure I am not blind.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: There lies the question?
For, but you say he is a man, and I
Will credit you, I should as soon have thought him
Another of god's creatures; out upon him,
His body, that can promise nothing
But laziness and long strides.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: These are your eyes;
Where were they Clora, when you fell in love
With the old footman, for singing of Queen Dido?
And swore he looked in his old velvet trucks
And his slyc't Spanish jerkin, like don John?
You had a perilous judgement then, my Clora.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Who told you that?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I heard it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Come, be friends,
The soldier is a Mars, no more, we are all
Subject to slide away.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay, laugh on still.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No faith, thou art a good wench, and 'tis pity
Thou shouldst not be well quarred at thy entering,
Thou art so high flown for him: look, who's there?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Prithee go single, what should I do there,
Thou knowest I hate these visitations,
As I hate peace or perry.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Wilt thou never
Make a right man?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You make a right fool of me
To lead me up and down to visit women,
And be abused and laughed at; let me starve
If I know what to say, unless I ask 'em
What their shoes cost?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Fie upon thee, coward,
Canst thou not sing?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Thou knowest I can sing nothing
But Plumpion park.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou'lt be bold enough,
When thou art entered once.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I had rather enter
A breach: if I miscarry, by this hand
I will have you by'th ears for't.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Save ye ladies.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.l: Sweet brother I dare swear, you're welcome hither,
So is your friend;

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come, blush not, but salute 'em.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Good sir believe your sister; you are most welcome,
So is this worthy gentleman whose virtues
I shall be proud to be acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: She has found me out already, and has paid me;
Shall we be going?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Peace;
Your goodness lady
Will ever be afore us, for myself
I will not thank you single, lest I leave
My friend, this gentleman, out of acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: More of me yet?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would I were able sir,
From either of your worths to merit thanks.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But brother, is your friend thus sad still? methinks
'Tis an unseemly nature in a soldier.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What hath she to do with me, or my behaviour?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: He does but show so, prithee to him sister.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: If I do not break thy head, I am no christian,
If I get off once.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sir, we must entreat you
To think yourself more welcome, and be merry,
'Tis pity a fair man of your proportion
Should have a soul of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Very well;
Pray gentlewoman what would you have me say?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Do not you know sir?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not so well as you
That talk continually.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You have hither, sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I thank him, so he has,
Fair fall his sweet face for't.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Let my face
Alone, I would wish you, lest I take occasion
To bring a worse in question.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Meaning mine?
Brother, where was your friend brought up? has sure
Been a great lover in his youth of pottage,
They lie so dull upon his understanding.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: No more of that, thou'lt anger him at heart.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Then let him be more manly, for he looks
Like a great schoolboy that had been blown up
Last night at dust-point.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You will never leave
Till you be told how rude you are, fie Clora.
Sir will it please you sit?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And I'll sit by you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Woman be quiet, and be ruled I would wish you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have done, sir captain.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Art thou not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You are an ass, I'll tell you more anon.
You had better ha' been hanged then brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: You are grown a sullen fool; either be handsome,
Or by this light I'll have wenches bait thee;
Go to the gentlewoman, and give her thanks,
And hold your head up; what?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: By this light I'll brain thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now o my faith this gentleman does nothing
But it becomes him rarely; Clora, look
How well this little anger, if it be one,
Shows in his face.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes, it shows very sweetly.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay do not blush sir, o my troth it does,
I would be ever angry to be thus.
Fabritio, o my conscience if I ever
Do fall in love, as I will not forswear it
Till I am something wiser, it must be,
I will not say directly with that face,
But certainly, such another as that is,
And thus dispose my chance to hamper me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Dost thou hear this, and stand still?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You will prate still;
I would you were not women, I would take
A new course with ye.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why courageous?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: For making me a stone to whet your tongues on.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Prithee sweet captain.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Go, go spin, go hang.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Now could I kiss him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: If you long for kicking,
You're best come kiss me, do not though, I'd wish ye,
I'll send my footman to thee, he shall leap thee,
And thou wantest horsing: I'll leave ye ladies.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart you are unmannerly
To offer this unto a gentleman
Of his deserts, that comes so worthily
To visit me, I cannot take it well.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I come to visit you, you foolish woman?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ay, though you did sir, and for that I thank you,
I would be loath to lose those thanks; I know
This is but some odd way you have, and faith
It does become you well to make us merry;
I have heard often of your pleasant vein.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What wouldst thou ask more?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Pray thou scurvy fellow
Thou hast not long to live; adieu dear damsels,
You silthy women farewell, and be sober,
And keep your chambers.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Farewell old don Diego.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Away, away, you must not be so angry,
To part thus roughly from us; yet to me
This does not show, as if 'twere yours, the wars
May breed men something plain I know,
But not thus rude; give me your hand good sir
I know 'tis white, and —

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: If I were not patient,
What would become of you two prating housewives?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: For any thing I know, we would in to supper,
And there begin a health of lusty claret
To keep care from our hearts, and it should be —

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Faith to whom? Mark but this Jacamo.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Even to the handsomest fellow now alive.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Do you know such a one?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He may be guessed at,
Without much travel.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: There's another item.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And he should be a soldier.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Twould be better.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And yet not you sweet captain

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why not he?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Well; I shall live to see your husbands beat you,
And hiss 'em on like bandogs.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Green sicknesses and serving-men light on ye
With greasy codpieces, and woollen stockings,
The devil (If he dare deal with two women)
Be of your counsels: farewell plasterers —Exit Jacamo.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: This fellow will be mad at midsummer
Without all doubt.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I think so too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am sorry
He's gone in such a rage; but sure this holds him
Not every day.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Faith every other day
If he come near a woman.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: I wonder how his mother could endure
To have him in her belly he's so boisterous.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He's to be made more tractable I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes, if they taw him as they do whitleather
Upon an iron, or beat him soft like stockfish.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Laelia and her waiting woman with a veil.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Art sure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Yes, and another with him.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: The more the merrier; did you give that money
And charged it to be delivered where I showed you?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Yes, and what else you bade me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: That brave fellow,
Though he be old, whate'er he be, shows toughness,
And such a one I long for, and must have
At any price; these young soft melting gristles
Are only for my safer ends.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: They are here.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Give me my veil, and bid the boy go sing
That song above, I gave him: the sad song:
Now if I miss him, I am cursed, go wench
And tell 'em I have utterly forsworn
All company of men; yet make a venture
At last to let 'em in; thou knowest these things,
Do 'em to'th life.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I warrant you I am perfect.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Some ill woman for her use would give
A million for this wench, she is so subtle.

div.stage: Enter to the door Julio and Angilo.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Good sir desire it not, I dare not do it,
For since your last being here, sir, believe me
She has grieved herself out of all company,
And (Sweet soul) almost out of life too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Prithee,
Let me but speak one word.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: You will offend sir
And yet your name is more familiar with her
Then any thing but sorrow, good sir go.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: This little varlet hath her lesson perfect,
These are the baits they bob with.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Faith I will not.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I shall be chidden cruelly for this;
But you are such a gentleman —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: There's a new tyre-wench; peace, thou art well enough.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What, has she music?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Yes; for god's sake stay,
'Tis all she feeds upon.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Alas poor soul.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now will I pray devoutly, for there's need on't.

lg.l: Away delights, go seek some other dwelling,
Farewell false love, thy tongue is ever telling
For ever let me rest now from thy smarts,
That have been hard to thee, mine was not so.
Never again deluding love shall know me,
And all those griefs that think to overgrow me
For ever will I sleep, while poor maids cry,
With thee, men cannot mock us in the day.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mistress? not one word, mistress if I grieve ye
I can depart again.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let's go then quickly,
For if she get from under this dark cloud,
We shall both sweat I fear for't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Do but speak
Though you turn from me, and speak bitterly,
And I am gone, for that I think will please you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O that all women were thus silent ever,
What fine things they were.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have looked on me,
When (If there be belief in women's words
Spoken in tears) you swore you loved to do so.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: O me my heart!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now Julio play the man,
Or such another will undo thee:
Would I had any thing to keep me busy
I might not hear her; think but what she is,
Or I doubt mainly, I shall be i'th mash too.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: Pray speak again;

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Where is my woman?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Mercy upon me! what a face she has?
Would it were veiled again.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Why did you let
This flattering man in to me? did not I
Charge thee to keep me from his eyes again,
As carefully as thou wouldst keep thine own?
Thou hast brought me poison in a shape of heaven
Whose violence will break the hearts of all,
Of all weak women, as it has done mine,
That are such fools to love, and look upon him.
Good sir be gone, you know not what an ease
Your absence is.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: By heaven she is a wonder,
I cannot tell what 'tis, but I am squeamish.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Though I desire to be here more than heaven
As I am now, yet if my sight offend you,
So much I love to be commanded by you
That I will go: farewell —

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I should say something
Ere you depart, and I would have you hear me:
But why should I speak to a man that hates me?
And will but laugh at any thing I suffer?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If this be hate —

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Away, away deceiver.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now help me Angilo!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am worse than thou art.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Such tears as those might make another woman
Believe thee honest Julio: almost me
That know their ends, for I confess they stir me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What will become of me? I cannot go now
If you would hang me, from her: oh brave eye!
Steal me away for god's sake Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Alas poor man! I am lost again too strangely.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: No, I will sooner trust a crocodile
When he sheds tears, for he kills suddenly,
And ends our cares at once; or any thing
That's evil to our natures, than a man;
I find there is no end of his deceivings,
Nor no avoiding 'em, if we give way:
I was requesting you to come no more,
And mock me with your service, 'tis not well,
Nor honest to abuse us so far: you may love too;
For though, I must confess I am unworthy
Of your love every way: yet I would have you
Think I am somewhat too good to make sport of.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Will you believe me?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: For your vows and oaths,
And such deceiving tears as you shed now,
I will as you do, study to forget 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: Let me be most despised of men —

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: No more;
There is no new way left, by which your cunning
Shall once more hope to catch me; no, thou false man
I will avoid thee, and for thy sake all
That bear thy stamp; as counterfeit in love.
For I am open eyed again, and know thee.
Go, make some other weep, as I have done,
That dare believe thee: go, and swear to her
That is a stranger to thy cruelty,
And knows not yet what man is, and his lyings,
How thou diest daily for her: pour it out
In thy best lamentations; put on sorrow,
As thou canst, to deceive an angel, Julio,
And vow thyself into her heart, that when
